awd_titl_txt: Graph Structure, the Four Color Theorem, and Generalizations
awd_abstract_narration:
This work falls within the area of graph theory and is closely related to theoretical computer science and mathematical programming (operations research). A graph is an abstract mathematical notion used to model networks, such as telephone networks, transportation networks, or the Internet. Various problems arise in the study of such networks, and this research project is concerned with questions of structural nature. Why do some networks possess certain specific desirable properties, and others do not? A satisfactory answer can have many applications, ranging from better understanding of underlying structure, to the design of efficient algorithms, to practical computations. For instance, one such question answered previously by the investigator settles a question of George Polya from 1913, solves a problem that baffled theoretical computer scientists for quarter of a century, and has applications in economics. 

The central theme of this project is graph structure theory and its applications to coloring, flows, and algorithms. More specifically, the investigator will study the structure of graphs pertaining to the graph minor inclusion and will use those results to attack flow and coloring problems, as well as the problem of characterizing "Pfaffian graphs." Pfaffian graphs are of interest because they allow efficient computation of perfect matchings, and their rich theory is related to other areas. This research will require the development of new tools in graph structure theory. Improved bounds will have immediate applications to the design of efficient algorithms.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of the project was to develop graph structure theory and apply it to coloring problems, notably the Four Color Theorem and its generalizations. A major outcome has been providing an in-depth understanding of 3-colorability (of the vertices) of graphs embeddable on various surfaces. This work performed by the original PI (Robin Thomas), in collaboration with a former postdocs (and now faculty), Zdenek Dvorak and Daniel Kral, has resulted in a series of 7 papers altogether, most of which have appeared in the very top journal on graph theory, Journal of Combinatorial Theory (Series B). 

A particularly important result includes: A linear-time algorithm to decide 3-colorability (and find a 3-coloring, if it exists) of quadrangulations of a fixed surface. The algorithm also allows to prescribe the coloring for a bounded number of vertices. 

Significance of the work: This paper is a part of a series aimed at studying the 3-colorability of graphs (possibly with parallel edges, but no loops) on a fixed surface that are either triangle-free, or have their triangles restricted in some way. All colorings in the paper are proper, i.e., adjacent vertices have different colors. Embeddability in a surface is not a sufficient restriction by itself, as 3-colorability of planar graphs is well-known to be an NP-complete problem. However, restricting the triangles is natural in the light of the well-known theorem of Grötzsch stating that every planar triangle-free graph is 3-colorable. Quadrangulations of a surface represent an important special case of the problem, as evidenced by a theorem of Gimbel and Thomassen:
A triangle-free graph embedded in the projective plane is 3-colorable if and only if it has no subgraph isomorphic to a non-bipartite quadrangulation of the projective plane. In another paper of this series by the PI and the same collaborators, they showed how the above theorem could be generalized to graphs embedded on other surfaces.


Robin Thomas advised multiple graduate and undergraduate students and published several papers.  With the PhD student Thanh Dang they answered a question of Seymour about 2-connected graphs of large path-width and generalized it to 3- and 4-connected graphs. With the undergraduate student Rose McCarty they determined the extremal function for bipartite linklessly embeddable graphs.

With the student Youngho Yoo they obtained two results concerning extremal functions for triangle-free graphs with excluded minors. Another work resulted in solving the Erdos-Posa problem for the so-called A-paths of length zero modulo a prime. To provide more detail:

Packings and coverings of combinatorial objects satisfy an approximate duality relation which often leads to efficient approximation algorithms and fixed-parameter-tractability for otherwise NP-hard problems. This relation is also known as the Erdős-Pósa property, named after the classical result of Erdős and Pósa from 1965 that cycles in graphs satisfy this approximate duality. There have  been numerous works on whether various families of graphs such as paths and cycles with additional constraints satisfy the Erdős-Pósa property. One long-standing open problem was a question of Dejter and Neumann-Lara from 1978 asking when cycles of length L mod M satisfy the Erdős-Pósa property. Besides the canonical counterexample of a projective-planar grid showing that odd cycles do not satisfy the property, and a result of Thomassen from 1988 showing that cycles of length 0 mod M do satisfy the property for all M, this question had remained wide open, even for cycles of length 1 mod 3.

Motivated by a similar question for A-paths (paths with certain endpoint constraints, generalizing matchings), Youngho Yoo and Robin Thomas developed structure theorems for group-labelled graphs, where each edge is assigned a group element and the weight of a path or cycle is the sum of the elements on its edges. Applying these structural results, they showed that A-paths of length 0 mod p, where p is prime, satisfy the Erdős-Pósa property, thereby answering a question of Bruhn and Ulmer from 2018 and characterizing when A-paths of length L mod M (more generally, A-paths of a fixed weight in an arbitrary abelian group) satisfy the Erdős-Pósa property. Their structural framework also allowed them to readily make some progress on the question of Dejter and Neumann-Lara, showing that cycles of length L mod M satisfy the Erdős- Pósa property for all odd prime powers M.

The PI also helped in a significant way the PhD student Dantong Zhu in completing a highly nontrivial project determing the extremal function for graphs with excluded K_10 (complete graph on 10 vertices) as the minor. 

The broader impacts resulting from this effort include successful mentoring and graduation of several Ph.D. students (Thanh Dang, Alexander Hoyer, Youngho Yoo, and Dantong Zhu), as well as mentoring of an undergraduate, Rose McCarty. Ms. McCarty went on to complete a Ph.D. at the University of Waterloo and subsequently joined as a tenure-track faculty at Georgia Tech.
